Award.AwardTitle: GP-EXTRA: Bridge to the Geosciences for Community College Students
Award.AbstractNarration:
Advancements in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) are the engine that drives U.S. innovation, economic development, prosperity and security. The STEM enterprise is strengthened by engaging multiple perspectives and utilizing the full talent pool available throughout the nation. Efforts to broaden participation of traditionally underrepresented minority students in the STEM disciplines thus contributes to a vibrant, creative, and impactful STEM workforce for the future. With more than half of STEM undergraduate degree recipients now beginning their educational pathway in a community college, it is essential that effective strategies for supporting students interested in STEM disciplines as they make the transition between two-year and four-year institutions be identified, in order to sustain the recruitment and retention of students in the STEM pipeline.

Citrus College, in collaboration with the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR), the Center for Dark Energy Biosphere Investigations (C-DEBI) at the University of Southern California, and the Oak Crest Institute of Science, is implementing a cohort-based program to engage 20 minority undergraduate students per year (60 students total) in immersive experiences that will increase their interest in, and preparation for, continuing along geoscience education pathways. Students at Citrus College, a Hispanic Serving Institution, will engage in geomodules organized around the subfields of planetary, atmospheric, ocean, and environmental sciences. These geomodules will include research activities with scientists at the collaborating research institutions. A capstone 10-day mini-internship at UCAR will provide immersive atmospheric research, training, and fieldwork. Professional development, mentoring, science communication development, and cohort-development is woven across all four geomodules. Through these catalytic experiences, participating students are expected to deepen their interest in and knowledge of the geosciences, to better understand the multiple entry points into the field, and to build valuable professional skills and networks. Engaging underserved populations through this project is expected to both increase the number of diverse students transferring to baccalaureate programs in the geosciences and create a more diverse population of science-literate citizens to address current and future geoscience-related challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bridge to the Geosciences for Community College Students, a NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) project, was designed to increase the number of diverse and traditionally underserved community college students exposed to education and career options in the geosciences, who were retained in STEM majors and, who transferred to a university in a STEM major. To accomplish these goals, the project, led by Citrus College, a two-year Hispanic-serving institution in the Los Angeles area, developed cross-sector partnerships and engaged cohorts of students in a 9-month extra-curricular exploration that introduced them to a variety of geoscience subfields including planetary science, marine science and geobiology, atmospheric science, and environmental science. 

Participants traveled to partner sites including the Oak Crest Institute of Science (Monrovia, CA; 1-day visit), National Center for Atmospheric Research (Boulder, CO; 9-day visit), the USC Wrigley Marine Science Center (Catalina, CA; 3-day visit) and NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (Pasadena, CA; 1-day visit).  In the final project year, new partnerships with the Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences (CIRES) (Boulder, CO; 8-day visit replacing NCAR) and the Gravitational Wave Physics and Astronomy Center (CSU Fullerton, CA; 5-day workshop) welcomed participating students.  


Through the series of 'geomodules,' student participants (N=80; 83% underrepresented minority; 60% women; 76% first-generation, 83% low-income) visited each partner site during their project participation year. The visits provided opportunities to learn about the science at the site and the related career opportunities; conduct small-scale research (Boulder and Catalina); interact with scientists and interns; receive mentoring, education, and career advice; develop science communication skills; and, learn about research experiences and internships.  Each visit was preceded by an on-campus preparation session ensuring students were equipped to access the information related to the site visit. Woven across all on- and off-campus sessions were intentional opportunities for students to develop a cohesive peer community that would become a source of support during and beyond their project participation.


Students who were selected for participation in the project were those who had multiple risk factors that often limit STEM degree completion.  For example, a majority of participants were first-generation and low-income and, their transcripts showed many had mediocre grade point averages that may have prohibited them from transferring in a STEM major. Moreover, pre-participation surveys indicated selected students lacked STEM role models, had only cursory information about the geosciences and how their disciplinary interests fit into geoscience careers and, they generally indicated they had no or few friends who were STEM majors.  

   
Post-participation surveys, focus group interviews, and a review of transcripts showed myriad positive outcomes for students, including:

-Participating students enrolled in and successfully completed more units each term compared to pre-participation with higher grades and, as a result, moved towards transfer more rapidly;

-Students formed durable peer networks that supported their interests in STEM;

-Students' self-efficacy was increased as they recognized their ability to work rapidly under pressure during several of the modules; 

-Participants' science communication skills were improved which allowed them to more comfortably network and engage with professional role models;

-Students' likelihood of applying for and completing a summer research experience or internship were increased (46% obtained a research opportunity or internship post-participation);

-Interest in and understanding of the geosciences was significantly increased leading to changes in transfer major and long-term career plans for participants.  

Participant outcome data show that, to date, 85% (n=69) transferred to a four-year university or have been accepted for fall 2020 transfer. Among transfer students, 97% have remained in STEM majors with just two students switching to a non-STEM major at the time of transfer. Six of the 80 participants continue enrollment at the community college in STEM majors and, of the remaining participants, two have stopped out of college and the other three finished STEM associate degrees but have not responded to our requests for updates giving us no clarity as to their transfer or enrollment status.  Considering STEM attrition rates often exceed 50% at this level (Aulck et al, 2017; Chen, 2013), project outcomes are unprecedented. 

Additional benefits for faculty and the campus have also been noted. A future project will not only continue to test this novel model of experiential learning for STEM students as well as investigate the efficacy of embedded professional development for faculty and, the benefits of cross-sector partnerships for the college and the partnering organizations.
